etymologies: late Middle English: Latin, ‘carbuncle’ (the earliest sense in English), from Greek anthrax, anthrak- ‘coal, carbuncle’, with reference to the skin ulceration in humans

definitions: a serious bacterial disease of sheep and cattle, causing acute and often fatal septicemia, and also transmissible to humans.

notes.text: The disease is caused by the bacterium Bacillus anthracis, and in humans is most often marked by severe skin ulceration (malignant pustule) or serious lung disease (wool-sorters' disease).

shortDefinitions: serious bacterial disease of sheep and cattle

definitions: spores or cells of the bacterium that causes anthrax.
